questions.question: A 9-year-old boy presents with a 2-day history of swelling, redness, and pain around his left eye, worsening with eye movements. He had a recent upper respiratory infection. On examination, there is proptosis, restricted eye movement, and chemosis. Vision is intact. CT scan confirms orbital cellulitis. Which staging system is used to classify this condition?
questions.explanation: located behind the orbital septum. Complications Disc edema RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) due to optic nerve dysfunction Cavernous sinus thrombosis CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion) or CRVO (Central Retinal Venous Occlusion) Generalized septicemia or pyemia Investigations White cell count. Cultures: Blood, nasal discharge. X-ray PNS (sinusitis) High-resolution CT of the orbit, sinuses and brain (exclude a subperiosteal or intracranial abscess). MRI Lumbar puncture (if meningeal or cerebral signs develop). Staging Modified Chandler staging (Option A) system: Stage I: Preseptal cellulitis/ periorbital cellulitis (limited anterior to orbital septum) Stage II: Inflammatory orbital oedema/ Orbital cellulitis (Posterior to orbital septum) Stage III: Subperiosteal abscess Stage IV: Orbital abscess Stage V: Cavernous sinus thrombosis Treatment Antibiotics (IV) Empirical therapy treats orbital cellulitis by giving Ceftazidime, Vancomycin, and Metronidazole. Monitoring of optic nerve function Surgery Drainage of an orbital abscess or infected sinuses should be considered if there is a lack of response to antibiotics. Biopsy Severe optic nerve compression may warrant an emergency canthotomy/ cantholysis Van Herick classification (Option B) is used to describe the anterior chamber angle status in glaucoma, using ratio of anterior chamber depth to corneal thickness. ETDRS classification (Option C) is the Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study used in Diabetic retinopathy staging Shaffer grading (Option D) is used to describe anterior chamber angle status in glaucoma, categorizing the risk of angle closure.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with a large, painless orbital mass that has been causing progressive proptosis and visual disturbance. After imaging and biopsy, the mass is identified as malignant. What is the choice of treatment in this scenario, and what is its definition?

options.A: Evisceration, it involves removal of the contents of the eyeball, sclera preserved
options.B: Enucleation, it involves removal of the contents of the eyeball, sclera preserved
options.C: Enucleation, it involves removal of the entire eyeball including the sclera.
options.D: Exenteration, it involves the removal of all orbital contents

questions.explanation: removal of the globe together with the soft tissues of the orbit (eyeball and periorbita). Incision made along orbital margins. Indicated for malignant tumors or extensive disease. Debulking of the orbit is now often preferred over exenteration. Evisceration Removal of eyeball contents while preserving the scleral shell and extraocular muscles. (Option A ruled out) Less radical than enucleation; not typically used for malignancy. Enucleation Removal of the entire eyeball (globe), indicated in: Primary intraocular malignancies Aer severe trauma where the risk of sympathetic ophthalmitis may outweigh any prospect of visual recovery Blind painful or unsightly eyes Contraindication: Panophthalmitis (due to the risk of infection spreading to the brain). Key Differences Procedure Extent of Removal Indications Cosmetic and Functional Outcomes Exenteration All orbital contents (Eyeball + EOM + eyelids) Malignant tumors, extensive disease Significant cosmetic and functional deficits Evisceration Contents of the eyeball, sclera preserved Not typically used for malignancy Preserves some eye movement Enucleation Entire eyeball including sclera Malignant tumours, less radical than exenteration Allows for ocular prosthesis placement Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page no, 152.

questions.question: A 12-year-old patient presents to the OPD with a typical S-shaped deformity of the eyelid. On examination, the patient is found to have multiple café-au-lait spots and axillary freckling. Which of the following findings is most commonly observed in this condition?
questions.explanation: Manifestations in Neurofibromatosis Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) Lisch Nodules : Iris hamartomas, key diagnostic feature. (Option D) Glaucoma : Common, especially with orbital-facial involvement; may lead to asymmetric globe enlargement. Optic Nerve Glioma : Can cause strabismus and proptosis. Palpebral Neurofibroma : S-shaped deformity of the lid Choroidal Alterations : Detected via near-infrared reflectance imaging; potential diagnostic criteria. Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) Early-Onset Cataracts : Present in up to 80% of cases. (Option A ruled out) Optic Nerve Hamartomas : Found in some cases. Optic nerve sheath meningiomas (Option D ruled out) Combined Pigment Epithelial and Retinal Hamartomas : Also observed. B/L Acoustic neuroma (Option C ruled out) Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4874640/

questions.question: A 6-year-old child presents with gradual, painless unilateral proptosis and vision loss. Fundoscopic examination reveals optic atrophy. Imaging studies show fusiform growth along the optic nerve. What is the most appropriate management for this child, considering the tumor is stationary and the vision is still present?

options.A: Immediate surgical excision of the tumor

questions.explanation: allowing for regular monitoring of the tumor's progress. Optic Nerve Gliomas A slow-growing, tumor of astrocytes (Option D) It is generally a unilateral tumor that typically affects children (more common in females). More common in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1). Clinical features: Presents with gradual diminution of vision and increasing axial proptosis. RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) and optic atrophy, disc oedema. Gradual, painless, unilateral proptosis. Fundus findings: optic atrophy, papilledema, or venous engorgement. Investigations: X-rays: Rounded enlargement of the optic foramen CT scan & MRI: Fusiform growth along the optic nerve. Treatment: Observation to preserve the nerve as long as possible. Radiotherapy: For inoperable cases. (Option B ruled out) Chemotherapy : Used in specific cases when other treatments are not suitable. (Option D ruled out) Surgery (cosmetically unacceptable proptosis in a blind eye). (Option A ruled out) Reference: Parson’s Diseases of The Eye, 23rd Edition, Page no, 1155-1158.

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman presents with progressive, painless proptosis of the left eye and swelling in the temporal region of the face. On examination, she has boggy eyelid swelling, proptosis. A CT scan reveals hyperostosis of the sphenoid bone. Identify the false statement regarding the same.

options.A: CT scan shows tubular enlargement of the optic nerve
options.B: They are more common in middle-aged women.
options.D: They are slow-growing tumors from astrocytes in the optic nerve.

questions.explanation: originate from the meninges, the protective coverings of the brain and spinal cord. Astrocytes are the cells from which optic nerve gliomas arise, not meningiomas. Optic Nerve Tumor Overview A tumor from the meningo-epithelial cells from the arachnoid layer. More common in middle-aged women. (Option B ruled out) 2/3rd of the cases are secondary tumors, and the primary is an extension from intracranial meningioma, 1/3rd arise independently. Clinical features: The Hyot-Spencer triad includes progressive vision loss, optic atrophy, and opto-ciliary shunt vessels. Proptosis late features Restricted-up gaze (involvement of superior rectus). Gaze evoked amaurosis fugax (transient loss of vision ). Temporal fossa fullness due to the hyperostosis of the sphenoid bone. Types: Optic Nerve Gliomas (ectodermal tumors of the nerve) Meningiomas (mesodermal tumors of the sheath of the nerve). Meningioma Arise from or involve the sphenoid bone. Mostly spread extensively along the dura in forms of sheets rather than a globular mass (meningioma en plaque) Predominant feature is early visual loss. Patients present with swollen or atrophic optic discs, restriction of eye movements. Opticociliary shunt vessels are present More common in NF II (Option C ruled out) Biopsy: or any surgery which transgresses the dura is to be avoided unless the rate of growth suggests a malignant type of meningioma, when biopsy is indicated. High-resolution CT scans show tubular enlargement of the optic nerve (Option A ruled out) and useful vision is retained, the orbit may be explored and the lesion removed without endangering vision. Reference: Parson’s Diseases of The Eye, 23rd Edition, Page no, 1155-1160.

questions.question: Which of the following is not part of the classical triad of Sturge-Weber syndrome?

options.A: Port-wine stain (nevus flammeus) in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Bilateral optic nerve glioma Explanation: Bilateral optic nerve glioma (Option C): Not part of the classical triad of Sturge-Weber syndrome . This is a characteristic feature of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) , not SWS. Sturge-Weber is not associated with optic gliomas. Sturge-Weber Syndrome Feature Description Type Sporadic neurocutaneous (phakomatosis) disorder Gene involved Somatic activating mutation in the GNAQ gene Triad of SWS 1. Facial port-wine stain (in trigeminal nerve distribution) 2. Leptomeningeal angiomas 3. Ocular abnormalities (e.g. glaucoma) Skin Port-wine stain (nevus flammeus), typically in V1 (ophthalmic) division distribution CNS Leptomeningeal hemangiomatosis → seizures, hemiparesis, intellectual disability Eye Glaucoma (due to increased episcleral venous pressure), choroidal hemangioma Imaging CT shows tram-track calcifications , MRI shows leptomeningeal enhancement Onset Usually in infancy, presenting with seizures or developmental delay Management Antiepileptics, treatment of glaucoma, laser therapy for port-wine stain Port-wine stain (nevus flammeus) in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve (Option A): Included in the classical triad. The facial angioma, typically in the V1 area, is a key clinical clue. Secondary congenital glaucoma (Option B): Part of the classical triad. It arises due to vascular abnormalities increasing intraocular pressure. Ipsilateral meningeal hemangiomatosis (Option D): Leptomeningeal angiomas are part of the syndrome and cause neurological manifestations like seizures and hemiparesis. Reference: Yanoff and Duker Ophthalmology, 5th edition, page 852, 853, 854.

questions.question: A 7-year-old male child presents with rapidly progressing proptosis in the right eye, which starts suddenly and mimics an acute inflammatory process. Imaging shows a well-defined orbital mass with adjacent bone destruction. What is the most common histopathological subtype of this tumor?
questions.explanation: cases, particularly in children. Rhabdomyosarcoma Overview Most common so tissue sarcoma of childhood (90% of cases are seen in children under 16 year of age). It is the most common primary orbital malignancy in children Derived from undifferentiated mesenchymal cells, it is a connective tissue tumor with the potential to differentiate into striated muscle cells. Diagnosis Methods X-rays show bone destruction CT/MRI show irregular, well-defined tumors with bone damage. Definitive diagnosis: Biopsy. Histopathological Types Type Prevalence (%) Embryonal (Option B) 60% Alveolar (Option A ruled out) 31% Botryoid (Option C ruled out) 6% Spindle cells (Option D ruled out) 3% Anaplastic Rare Treatment Options Chemotherapy (Vincristine and actinomycin D) A combination of radiotherapy, chemotherapy and sometimes surgical debulking.

questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presents with painless proptosis of the right eye for the past year. She denies any visual changes, pain, or other ocular symptoms. On examination, there is mild proptosis. MRI reveals a well-defined, intraconal mass with homogeneous enhancement, suggestive of a cavernous hemangioma. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation: significant cosmetic concerns, observation with regular follow-up is the preferred management. Cavernous hemangioma of orbit: It is a low-flow, non-distensible orbital venous malformation The primary location is intraconal space Common in middle-aged females Clinical manifestation: Variable size, smooth contours, and noninvasive Gradual-onset axial proptosis, blurred vision, pain, or diplopia Compressive optic neuropathy Diagnosis: USG- Well-circumscribed, round-to-oval lesion with high internal reflectivity, a regular acoustic structure with poor vascular flow Contrast-enhanced CT Valsalva-augmented MRI Treatment: (Option D) Asymptomatic cases: Observation and periodic follow-up Indications for surgical excision are: (Option A ruled out) Symptomatic CVMs Visual loss due to optic nerve compression Disfiguring proptosis Dystopia Other treatment options are stereotactic radiotherapy, pre-operative embolization percutaneous sclerotherapy, and intralesional injection of pingyangmycin (bleomycin A5) (Options B & C ruled out) Reference: Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition, page 1154 Orbital Vascular Anomalies - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Image; Prepladder notes

questions.question: Which among the following statements is/are true regarding orbital varices? Proptosis worsens with the Valsalva maneuver. It is thin-walled distensible high-flow veins. Venous stasis can lead to the formation of phlebolith. Endovascular embolization is contraindicated.
questions.explanation: the formation of phlebolith. Orbital varices: It is a plexus of thin-walled dilated low-flow vein (Statement 2 ruled out) Clinical manifestation: Soft-tissue compressible swelling with a ‘bag of worms’ Proptosis, diplopia, visual disturbances, or ecchymosis Distension on dependent position, coughing or Valsalva maneuver (Statement 1) Diagnosis: Dynamic investigations, such as Valsalva-augmented MRI/CT Venous stasis can lead to the formation of a phlebolith , which is visualized on CT or plain X-ray (Statement 3) Treatment: Endovascular embolization (Statement 4 ruled out) CO2 laser ablation Surgical excision is very difficult due to the friable nature with the tendency to bleed Reference: Parsons diseases of the eye 23rd edition page 1154 Orbital Varices - EyeWiki Orbital Vascular Anomalies - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov)

questions.question: A 35-year-old man presents with a progressive painless swelling in the superolateral part of his left orbit over the past year. Examination reveals mild proptosis and downward and inward displacement of the eye. CT of the orbit shows a well-circumscribed, smooth, encapsulated mass in the lacrimal gland region. Excisional biopsy is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: lacrimal gland tumor Incidence- young adult males Clinical manifestation: Slow-growing painless swelling in the upper-outer quadrant of the orbit Displaces the eyeball downwards and inwards Diagnosis: Imaging: CT- well-defined mass in superotemporal quadrant Histology: The inner layer of cells forms glandular tissue associated with squamous differentiation and keratin production. The outer cells undergo metaplastic change leading to the formation of myxoid tissue Treatment: Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option A), Squamous cell carcinoma (Option B), and Lymphoma (Option D): All of them are lacrimal gland malignancies typically present as a painful, rapidly growing mass in the superotemporal quadrant of the orbit, causing displacement of the eye in an inferonasal direction. CT scans often reveal an infiltrative tumor. Complete excision with the capsule

questions.question: Which is the most common non-epithelial malignant lacrimal gland tumor?
questions.explanation: tumors: Swelling of the gland may cause limitations in eye movements. Inferonasal dystopia (globe is pushed downwards and inwards) Proptosis Most common lacrimal gland tumor Pleomorphic adenoma Most common malignant lacrimal gland tumor Adenoid cystic carcinoma (Option B ruled out) Most common non-epithelial malignant lacrimal gland tumor Lymphoma (Option C) Pleomorphic adeno-carcinoma (Option A): It is an epithelial malignant tumor. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma (Option D): It is an epithelial malignant tumor and accounts for only 5% of the malignant epithelial lacrimal gland tumors.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with double vision, drooping of the right eyelid, and difficulty moving his right eye in multiple directions. On examination, the patient has normal visual acuity, ptosis, restricted eye movement, decreased sensation over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex on the same side. What is the most likely diagnosis and which cranial nerve is/are most likely affected in this condition?

options.A: Superior orbital fissure syndrome; III, IV, V, and VI nerves
options.C: Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III and IV nerves

questions.explanation: V1 (ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve), and VI (abducens), which pass through the superior orbital fissure. Clinical manifestation of ptosis (III), ophthalmoplegia (III, IV, VI), sensory loss over the forehead, and absent corneal reflex (V1) points towards the diagnosis of this syndrome. Superior orbital fissure syndrome: Also known as the Rochon-Duvigneaud syndrome. (Option D ruled out) It is caused by compression of structures anterior to the orbital apex. Etiology: Most common cause is trauma Idiopathic Neoplasias Meningitis, syphilis, sinusitis, herpes zoster Inflammation - Lupus, sarcoidosis, Tolosa-Hunt syndrome (Episodes of unilateral orbital pain, cranial nerve involved and granulomatous inflammation) Vascular phenomena - carotid-cavernous fistulas, retro-orbital hematoma, and carotid aneurysms Pathophysiology: Involvement of the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure (III, IV, VI, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve). (Option A) Clinical features: Pain (retro-orbital ache) Sensory loss in the distribution of ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve Absent corneal reflex Decreased sensation over the forehead Ipsilateral ophthalmoplegia due to 3rd, 4th, and 6th cranial nerve involvement Ptosis due to 3rd nerve paralysis Investigations: CT, MRI Angiography- vascular causes of the syndrome Orbital apex syndrome; optic nerve (Option B) : It is a symptom complex due to the involvement of structures present at the apex of the orbit (structures passing through the superior orbital fissure and the optic canal) So the cranial nerves involved are II, III, IV, V, and VI Optic nerve (II) involvement causes visual loss and afferent pupillary defect Tolosa Hunt syndrome; II, III, and IV nerves (Option C) : It is idiopathic nonspecific granulomatous inflammation involving the cavernous sinus and orbital apex causing compression of surrounding nerves. Commonly manifests as painful ophthalmoplegia and presents as superior orbital fissure syndrome or orbital apex syndrome depending upon the extent of involvement Clinical manifestations in this scenario suggest there is no involvement of the optic nerve (II) Reference: Orbital Apex Syndrome - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf (nih.gov) Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome - EyeWiki

questions.question: A 50-year-old male, recently recovered from COVID-19, presents with complaints of severe facial pain, nasal congestion, and black eschar on the left eye with periorbital pain. He has a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus. On examination, the following is seen. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: particularly in immunocompromised patients with uncontrolled diabetes. Rhino Orbital Cerebral Mucormycosis Etiology Fungal infection (Mucoraceae, primarily Mucor and Rhizopus species). (Option B) Risk factors Immunocompromised individuals Clinical Features Facial and periorbital swelling, pain, proptosis, diplopia, fever. (similar to orbital cellulitis) Tissue necrosis (tissue ischemia) Aspergillus species, Candida species, Cryptococcus neoformans (Options A, C and D ruled out) do not cause Mucormycosis. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 126.

questions.question: A 32-year-old male had blunt trauma to the face during a sports event. He reports difficulty moving his right eye upward and experiences double vision when looking up. On examination, there is tenderness at the right infraorbital rim, and the patient exhibits noticeable swelling and bruising around the right eye. Which wall of the orbit is most likely affected in this case?
questions.explanation: upward gaze) and diplopia (double vision) when looking up. These symptoms are characteristic of a blowout fracture. Bones of Orbit Medial Wall (Thinnest): Frontal process of maxilla (anterior-most) Lacrimal bone Orbital plate of ethmoid (posterior to lacrimal process) Body of sphenoid (posterior-most) Lateral Wall (Strongest): ( Option B ruled out) Orbital surface of zygomatic bone (anterior part) Orbital surface of greater wing of sphenoid (posterior part) Floor: Orbital surface of body of maxilla (medial part) Orbital surface of zygomatic bone (anterolateral part) Orbital process of the palatine bone (posteromedial part) Roof: Orbital plate of the frontal bone (anterior part) Lesser wing of the sphenoid (posterior part) Key features: Weakest Wall of the Orbit: Medial wall is the thinnest due to the cribriform plate of ethmoid. (Option A) Blowout Fracture : Fracture of floor of the orbit due to blunt trauma. (Option C) Weakest Part of the Floor: Posteromedial Part of the orbit. Roof (Option D): Symptoms and examination findings are more suggestive of orbital floor fracture due to blunt trauma in this scenario.

questions.question: A 10-year-old girl presents with a swollen, painful left eye that started after a recent cold. She is febrile and on examination, her left eyelid is erythematous and swollen, with chemosis, proptosis, limited ocular movement but normal visual acuity. What is the most common primary source of this eye infection in the child?
questions.explanation: ethmoid sinus is part of the medial wall. Orbital cellulitis Definition Orbital cellulitis is an acute infection of the soft tissues of the orbit located behind the orbital septum. Etiology Sinusitis: Ethmoid sinusitis (most common) carries a high risk of causing orbital cellulitis. (Option A) Underlying dental problem. Dacryocystitis (inflammation of the lacrimal sac). Endogenous cause: Septicemia Exogenous cause: Fracture or surgery of the orbit. Causative Organisms Staphylococcus aureus (most common) Haemophilus influenzae (most common in children) Streptococcus pneumoniae Streptococcus pyogenes Clinical Features Painful, unilateral Proptosis (swelling and severe pain worsened by eye movement or pressure) Restriction of eye movements (due to proptosis) Decreased visual acuity Lid edema conjunctival congestion / chemosis Systemic symptoms: like fever, headache, nausea Complications Disc edema RAPD (Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect) due to optic nerve dysfunction Cavernous sinus thrombosis CRAO (Central Retinal Artery Occlusion) or CRVO (Central Retinal Venous Occlusion) Generalized septicemia or pyemia. Preseptal Cellulitis

questions.question: A 25-year-old male presents with intermittent bulging of his right eye, worsening with cough and bending forward. His vision is intact, and there is no history of trauma or infection. What is the most likely cause of his condition?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Orbital varix Explanation: The intermittent proptosis triggered by cough and bending forward, along with the absence of pain or inflammation, suggests a vascular cause like orbital varix. Causes of intermittent proptosis: Orbital varix (Option B) Periodic orbital oedema Recurrent orbital hemorrhage Highly vascular tumors Orbital Varices Dilated venous channels in the orbit (part of the spectrum of developmental venous anomalies) Clinical features Most cases are unilateral and the most frequent site is upper nasal. Slowly progressive intermittent proptosis which worsens with head position changes, bending forward, or Valsalva maneuver. Pathology May involve one large vessel or multiple ectatic veins with fibrotic walls. Thrombosed lumens can contain phleboliths from calcified thrombi. Imaging CT - serpiginous, dense structures that enlarge with Valsalva, enhances with contrast administration. MRI - T1 images show low isointense signal, T2 shows dark signal void from flowing blood. Enhancement with Gadolinium is marked, except in areas of thrombosis. Treatment No treatment needed for mild symptoms; Surgical or embolization options for severe cases. Prognosis Good unless large lesions compress the optic nerve, risking vision loss. Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Option A) typically presents with severe pain, ophthalmoplegia , and rapid onset symptoms, unlike this slow intermittent presentation. Thyroid orbitopathy (Option C) usually causes bilateral , progressive proptosis , not intermittent bulging. Orbital cellulitis (Option D) presents with acute onset, pain, fever, and signs of infection , which are absent here. Reference: Yanoff and Duker Ophthalmology, 5th Edition, Page 1328 Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th Edition, Page 135

questions.question: A 48-year-old man presents with a complaint of eye protrusion. He describes experiencing a rhythmic, pulsatile sensation in his right eye for the past few weeks. Which of the following is NOT a likely cause ?

options.B: Saccular aneurysm of the ophthalmic artery

questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) Orbital cellulitis Explanation: This presentation suggests pulsatile proptosis . Pulsatile proptosis, also known as pulsatile exophthalmos , is a condition that causes the eyeball to protrude and pulsate. Orbital cellulitis typically causes proptosis due to inflammation and swelling within the orbit. Orbital cellulitis often presents with pain, redness, swelling, and fever, without the rhythmic pulsation characteristic of pulsatile proptosis. Causes of Pulsatile Proptosis Carotico-cavernous Fistula: Abnormal connection between the carotid artery and the cavernous sinus (Option A ruled out) . Saccular Aneurysm of the Ophthalmic Artery: Aneurysm located on the ophthalmic artery causing pulsatile proptosis (Option B ruled out) . Congenital Meningocele or Meningoencephalocele: Protrusion of the meninges or brain through a defect in the orbital roof (Option C ruled out) . Neurofibromatosis: Genetic disorder causing tumors on nerve tissue, which can affect orbital structures. Traumatic or Operative Hiatus: Defects in the orbital roof resulting from trauma or surgery, allowing transmitted cerebral pulsations Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 10th Edition, Page 136, 834

questions.question: If a patient with thyroid eye disease exhibits stable symptoms with no acute inflammation and has experienced a gradual improvement in symptoms over the past 1-2 years, which stage of Rundle’s Curve is most likely being described?
questions.explanation: inflammation, they are in the Chronic or “Burnt-Out” Stage, where further changes are unlikely. In the chronic or "burnt-out" stage of thyroid eye disease, the condition has stabilized after reaching its peak severity. This stage is characterized by stable symptoms that have ceased worsening, the absence of acute inflammation indicating the end of the most active phase, and a gradual improvement in symptoms over the preceding months to years, reflecting the natural progression towards stabilization. Rundle’s Curve and Thyroid Eye Disease: Phase Details Initial Phase (Option A ruled out) Duration A few months. Characteristics Progressive worsening of symptoms. Peak Phase (Option B ruled out) Characteristics The disease reaches its maximum severity. Improvement Phase (Option C ruled out) Duration 1-2 years. Characteristics Symptoms start to improve spontaneously, transitioning from acute to chronic. Chronic or “Burnt-Out” Stage (Option D) Characteristics Disease stabilizes; further changes are unlikely. Treatment Focus Typically requires surgical intervention. Active Disease Features Acute inflammation. Timing Early phase of Rundle’s curve. Treatment Potentially responsive to medical treatments. Inactive Disease Features Stabilized disease with no acute inflammation. Treatment Requires surgical options for altering outcomes. Significance of Rundle’s Curve Defines the natural progression of thyroid eye disease and guides treatment choices based on disease phase and severity. Reference: https://www.bmj.com/content/bmj/338/7695/Clinical_Review.full.pdf

questions.question: A 52-year-old woman with a history of thyroid disease presents with difficulty closing her eyes, noticeable eye protrusion and prominent bilateral lid retraction giving a staring and frightened appearance of the eyes as shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the sign observed in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Kocher’s sign Explanation: The Kocher sign describes a staring and frightened appearance of the eyes with severe bilateral lid retraction which is particularly marked on attentive fixation. This sign directly correlates with the observed prominent lid retraction in the patient. Clinical Features: Clinical Features Details Lid Signs Dalrymple's Sign Upper lid retraction causing a staring appearance (90% of cases). Von Graefe's Sign Lid lag when the globe moves downward (50% of cases). (Option A ruled out) Enroth's Sign Puffy, oedematous swelling of the eyelids. Gifford's Sign Difficulty in eversion of the upper lid. Stellwag's Sign Infrequent blinking. (Option C ruled out) Joffroy's Sign Poor forehead wrinkling on looking up. (Option D ruled out) Kocher’s sign Increased lid retraction with visual fixation (staring look) Conjunctival Signs Deep Injection Pronounced redness. Chemosis Swelling of the conjunctiva. Pupillary Signs Less significant; may show unequal dilatation of pupils. Ocular Motility Defects Mobius's Sign Convergence weakness. Restrictive Myopathy Limited movement in the direction opposite to the affected muscle. Exophthalmos Both eyes are often affected with possible unilateral proptosis.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman with a history of thyroid disease presents with bilateral eye bulging and difficulty closing her eyes. On examination, there is noticeable eye protrusion, eyelid swelling, and restricted extraocular movements. Which of the following best describes the pathogenesis of her eye condition?

options.A: Extraocular muscles are the primary target of inflammation.
options.B: The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is depression.
options.C: T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit.
options.D: Inflammation is primarily due to neutrophils.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) T-cells attack the orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes in the orbit. Explanation: This scenario is related to thyroid eye disease (Graves’ orbitopathy), where T-cells attack orbital fibroblasts and adipocytes. This autoimmune response causes inflammation, increased fat formation, and swelling, leading to eye protrusion and eyelid swelling. The extraocular muscles are affected secondarily. Pathogenesis of Thyroid Eye Disease (Graves' Orbitopathy) It involves an organ-specic autoimmune reaction in which anti-thyrotropin-receptor antibody reacts against thyroid gland cells and orbital broblasts. Insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor (IGF-1R) and the thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor (TSHR) are upregulated in orbital and brow fat, leading to inflammation of extraocular muscles, interstitial tissues, orbital fat and lacrimal glands. Osmotic imbibition of water (pleomorphic cellular infiltration (Option D ruled out) and increased secretion of glycosaminoglycans) and lipogenesis induced by broblasts and preadipocytes, which causes orbital fat enlargement. Optic nerve may be compression (increased IOP). Subsequent degeneration of muscle fibres results in restrictive myopathy and diplopia. Primary Target : Orbital fibroblasts Secondary Involvement : Extraocular muscles (Option A ruled out) . Optic nerve compression in thyroid ophthalmopathy is typically due to increased orbital volume (from inflammation and muscle swelling), not from vascular occlusion. The increase in orbital contents can compress the optic nerve, leading to visual disturbances. The earliest defective ocular movement seen in this patient is elevation . (Option B) Reference: Kanski’s clinical ophthalmology, 9th edition, Pages 118-119.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of pseudoproptosis?
questions.explanation: of the eye (exophthalmos) due to swelling. This is not an example of pseudoproptosis, which involves the appearance of protrusion without actual displacement of the eye. Pseudoproptosis: Pseudoproptosis is a condition in which the eyeball appears to be proptosed but actually there is no forward displacement. Causes of Pseudoproptosis It is seen in high myopia (due to increase in size of eyeball) (Option A ruled out) . Llid retraction (Option B ruled out) . Shallow orbits (exorbitism) Contralateral ptosis Unilateral enophthalmos. (Option C ruled out) . Reference: Parson’s Diseases of The Eye, 23rd Edition, Page no, 1132.

questions.question: A 34-year-old woman with a history of hyperthyroidism presents with bilateral proptosis and difficulty closing her eyes. To assess the degree of eye protrusion, a Hertel's exophthalmometer is used. Which of the following statements regarding the use of the exophthalmometer is correct?

options.A: Normal values for exophthalmometer readings are typically between 20 and 30 mm.
options.B: Difference of 2–3 mm or more between the two eyes is suspicious regardless of the absolute values
options.C: A reading greater than 10 mm in both eyes is indicative of proptosis.
options.D: Hertel's exophthalmometer can only be used to measure the degree of proptosis in one eye at a time.

questions.explanation: the absolute values measures the forward displacement of both eyes simultaneously (Option D) , providing a more accurate and consistent measurement of proptosis and identifying asymmetry between the eyes. Clinical evaluation of proptosis Differentiate proptosis from pseudoproptosis Pseudoproptosis (the false impression of proptosis) may be due to facial asymmetry, enlargement of the globe (high myopia, buphthalmos), lid retraction or contralateral enophthalmos. Asymmetrical proptosis is readily detected by looking down at the patient from above and behind Globe location: If it is misplaced superiorly, inferiorly, medially, laterally, or straight out (axially) by an exophthalmometer. An exophthalmometer is used to quantify the distance from the orbital rim to the corneal surface of each eye in order to assess the symmetry of globe protrusion. Readings >21 mm are indicative of proptosis (Option C) and a difference of 2–3 mm or more between the two eyes is suspicious regardless of the absolute values. (Option B) Hertel's exophthalmometer: In adults. Luedde exophthalmometer: In children. Naugle exophthalmometer: Non-axial proptosis

questions.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the orbital foramina and fissures?

options.A: Superior orbital fissure is between the medial and lateral walls.
options.B: Inferior orbital fissure is between the lesser wing of the sphenoid and the maxillary bone.
options.C: Optic foramen is between the lateral wall and the orbital floor.
options.D: Optic nerve and ophthalmic artery pass through the optic foramen.

questions.explanation: ophthalmic artery Superior Orbital Fissure: A bony cleft found at the orbital apex between the roof and lateral wall. Located between the lesser and greater wings of the sphenoid bone. (Option A ruled out) Inferior Orbital Fissure: Defined as a space between the lateral wall and the orbital floor. Present between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the maxillary bone . (Option B ruled out) Optic Foramen: Part of the roof of the orbit . It is between lesser wing and body of sphenoid. (Option C ruled out) Essential for the morphogenesis of the eye during embryologic development. Structures Passing Through the Optic Foramen: (Option D) Optic Nerve Ophthalmic Artery
